description: All the elements are there! We have a rock, a handle, rubber-strips and a leather pouch.
Let's create a new web component: slingshot. This one will have references to all the other elements.
The order of the other elements is as follows: rock, leather-pouch, rubber-strip (twice) and handle.
For the rubber-strips, can you add one for the left side and one for the right? Pull this into properties of the slingshot too, please!
You don't need properties for the rock and the handle. They're fine as is. After you're done, you should see your slingshot come to life!
followUpMessage: Great slingshot! But don't we need to pull on the pouch so that it's ready to fire?

exercises.hint:
<link rel="import" href="lib/polymer/polymer-element.html">
<link rel="import" href="leather-pouch.html">
<link rel="import" href="rubber-strip.html">
<link rel="import" href="handle.html">
<link rel="import" href="rock.html">

<dom-module id="slingshot">
    <template>
        <rock></rock>
        <leather-pouch></leather-pouch>
        <rubber-strip side="[[_leftSide]]"></rubber-strip>
        <rubber-strip side="[[_rightSide]]"></rubber-strip>
        <handle></handle>
    </template>
</dom-module>

<script>
    class Slingshot extends Polymer.Element {

        static get is() {
            return 'slingshot';
        }

        static get properties() {
            return {
                _leftSide: {
                    type: String,
                    value: 'Left',
                },
                _rightSide: {
                    type: String,
                    value: 'Right',
                },
            };
        }
    }

    window.customElements.define(Slingshot.is, Slingshot);
</script>
